body_html:
Named arguments work for me when the first argument to torch.norm() is a torch.autograd.Variable; using torch.Tensor causes exceptions.

MWE:

#!/usr/bin/python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-

from __future__ import print_function

import torch
import torch.autograd


t = torch.ones(1, 1)
v = torch.autograd.Variable(t)

print(torch.version.__version__)
torch.norm(v, dim=1)
torch.norm(t, p=2, dim=1)
torch.norm(t, dim=1)

Output:

christoph:/tmp$ python --version
Python 2.7.13 :: Anaconda, Inc.
christoph:/tmp$ conda --version
conda 4.3.30
christoph:/tmp$ python tensor-vs-variable.py 
0.2.0+547ac8c
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "tensor-vs-variable.py", line 16, in <module>
    torch.norm(t, dim=1)
TypeError: torch.norm received an invalid combination of arguments - got (torch.FloatTensor, dim=int), but expected one of:
 * (torch.FloatTensor source)
 * (torch.FloatTensor source, float p)
      didn't match because some of the keywords were incorrect: dim
 * (torch.FloatTensor source, float p, int dim)
 * (torch.FloatTensor source, float p, int dim, bool keepdim)

body:
Named arguments work for me when the first argument to `torch.norm()` is a `torch.autograd.Variable`; using `torch.Tensor` causes exceptions.

MWE:
```python
#!/usr/bin/python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-

from __future__ import print_function

import torch
import torch.autograd


t = torch.ones(1, 1)
v = torch.autograd.Variable(t)

print(torch.version.__version__)
torch.norm(v, dim=1)
torch.norm(t, p=2, dim=1)
torch.norm(t, dim=1)
```

Output:
```
christoph:/tmp$ python --version
Python 2.7.13 :: Anaconda, Inc.
christoph:/tmp$ conda --version
conda 4.3.30
christoph:/tmp$ python tensor-vs-variable.py 
0.2.0+547ac8c
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "tensor-vs-variable.py", line 16, in <module>
    torch.norm(t, dim=1)
TypeError: torch.norm received an invalid combination of arguments - got (torch.FloatTensor, dim=int), but expected one of:
 * (torch.FloatTensor source)
 * (torch.FloatTensor source, float p)
      didn't match because some of the keywords were incorrect: dim
 * (torch.FloatTensor source, float p, int dim)
 * (torch.FloatTensor source, float p, int dim, bool keepdim)
```
